CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, May 12, 1956, pg. 15, reads: "'I'm Clean!' - That's what this suspect, caught in the dope dragnet, Friday, tells Acting Lieut. Alan Carnahan, Assistant Police Superintendent Lawrence J. Maloney and Morals Court Magistrate E. N. Johnson at a hearing early Saturday morning in the Armory. - Harris Photo."  Portions of accompanying article by Frank Bolden read: "Biggest 'Haul' in Local Police History - Nab 150 in Big Dope Dragnet - We rendezvoused at 6 P.M., according to instructions.  Upon entering the huge armory on Saw Mill Run Boulevard, we met several old friends, including those from the identification department of the city Police Department and other newspaper friends.  All agreed that 'something's up,' and that 'something' was something BIG.  Of course, all knew.  But all had been sworn to secrecy.  Plans had been in the making for the past nine months and more.  After exchanging additional greetings, we were informed that if we wished, we could go nearby and have a 'bite to eat,' as we had the time.  With companions John Clark and 'Teenie' Harris of the Courier, I accepted the invitation, because it would probably ne many hours before we would have a chance to eat again..."  "Just before 9 P. M., after officers had been briefed, a mobilized force of more than 260 police officers - city, county, state and Federal - broken down into 15 squad, roared away from the armory, fanned out and began the search for the known dope addicts, 'pushers' and vagrants who were in the company of the former types of suspects..." "In Pittsburgh and Clairton agents carried 69 Federal warrants charging dope peddlers.  In additions, agents sought out addicts (users), 'junkies,' marijuana smokers and others in possession of barbiturates..."
TitMainTitle: Man exposing arms to Acting Lieutenant Alan Carnahan, Assistant Superintendent of Police Lawrence J. Maloney, and Morals Court Magistrate E. N. Johnson, in Saw Mill Run Boulevard armory
